cs.CL, cs.IR, cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.CY

The paper deals with a new dataset for sequential sentence classification in medical abstracts. The dataset is based on PubMed, which is a database of biomedical literature. The paper discusses the need for better tools to efficiently skim through the literature, especially in fields where abstracts may be long, such as the medical field. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the Natural Language Processing (NLP) sub-category of Computer Science. Specifically, the paper deals with text classification, which is a common task in NLP. Therefore, cs.CL (Computation and Language) is the most likely sub-category. 

The paper also discusses the need for more accurate algorithms for sequential short-text classification. This suggests that the paper may also belong to the Information Retrieval (IR) sub-category, which deals with the retrieval of relevant information from large collections of text. Therefore, cs.IR is the second most likely sub-category. 

The paper also mentions the release of a new large dataset, which could be useful for developing more accurate algorithms. This suggests that the paper may also belong to the Machine Learning (ML) sub-category, which deals with the development of algorithms that can learn from data. Therefore, cs.LG (Learning) and cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) are the third and fourth most likely sub-categories.
